awd_titl_txt: Exploring & Exploiting the Dynamic Optical Sky
awd_abstract_narration:
For millennia, human beings have noticed "new stars" appearing and disappearing in the night sky. Thanks to advances in sensors, computation and algorithms astronomers are now able to discover millions of changes in the night sky. The objects range from near-earth asteroids to explosive stellar deaths across the Universe. This vibrant field of “time-domain astronomy” is now addressing fundamental scientific questions such as the origin of the elements in the Universe, as well as playing a critical role in identifying exotic astronomical events which are bright in gravitational waves or neutrinos and providing unique insights into stars. Time-domain astronomy is one of the four scientific pillars of the Vera Rubin Observatory, the NSF’s high priority ground-based observatory for the next decade. The Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) is preparing the astronomy community including students to become adept users of the Rubin Observatory.  ZTF-II builds on the success of ZTF-I which began survey operations in March 2018 and has been responsible for 50% of global supernova discoveries over the past year, along with a slew of other discoveries from both the real-time alert stream and the multi-billion object catalog releases.  This award advances the goals of the Windows on the Universe Big Idea via ZTF’s strong relevance to Multi-Messenger Astrophysics.

ZTF-II is a state-of-the art time-domain survey employing a 47 square degrees field-of-view camera on the Palomar 48-inch Samuel Oschin Schmidt telescope. It operates a public survey covering the visible northern sky (declination above -30 degrees) every 2 nights in g- and r-bands to about 20.5 magnitude. Each ZTF observation is processed by an image differencing pipeline which generates real-time alerts for all 5-sigma detections of point-source transient events, amounting to several hundred thousand alerts per night. These alerts contain thumbnail images of the discovery image, a reference image, and the difference between the two, as well as a 30-day light curve history, and various metadata, such as a real-bogus score, details of the nearest PS1 source, and pipeline parameters. Daily spectral classifications of all supernovae brighter than 18.5 mag are obtained using a robotic spectrometer and announced via the Transient Name Server.  Each ZTF observation is also processed by a Point Spread Function photometry pipeline which produces a single epoch catalog covering all identified sources. These are archived at IPAC and used to create light-curves for all detected objects in ZTF data releases - in ZTF-II, these will be released on a 2-month cycle starting in 2021.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) is a powerful optical sky survey designed for fast, wide area coverage to identify rare, fast-varying astronomical sources. It employs a state-of-the-art camera with a 47 square degree field-of-view (the full Moon is 0.2 square degrees) mounted on the Samuel Oschin 48-inch Schmidt telescope at Palomar Observatory in Southern California. Over the past three years, ZTF has covered the entire Northern Sky once every two nights in red and green filters, observing billions of astronomical objects several hundred times. Detections of changes in brightness or position of any of these objects are sent out in real time to the community, amounting to several hundred thousand alerts per night. The resulting "light curves" of variable and explosive objects have been a major source of such data for not only the US but also the global astronomical community.


ZTF has discovered over 10,000 supernovae (SNe), including over 7600 "Type Ia", originating in stellar binary systems with at least one white dwarf companion, and over 2100 "Type II", produced by the collapse of massive stars, as well as numerous examples of other types. This vast trove explains in part the impact ZTF has had in the field of cosmic explosions. Additionally, ZTF's fast coverage means that many SNe are discovered early, before they have peaked in brightness, and this is changing our understanding of the nature of supernova progenitor systems and the physics of their explosions. Many of these SNe have also been classified autonomously with machine learning which has made ZTF a far more efficient discovery engine. ZTF has also detected a rare example of a SNe lensed by the gravity of another galaxy into multiple images on the sky. This can tell us about the amount and distribution of matter in the inner core of the lensing galaxy and tell us about the expansion history of the universe. 


When a star gets too close to a massive black hole in the center of a galaxy, it is pulled apart by tidal forces and energy is released as material falls into the black hole. These tidal disruption events (TDEs) are rare events but ZTF has detected over a hundred, increasing the number of optical TDEs known by several tens. This has provided important clues about the physical properties and parameters of such interactions. In particular, one of the TDEs was seen to have a relativistic jet associated with it, which is only possible if the black hole is spinning very rapidly. ZTF is also showing that the environment of a supermassive black hole is generally far more dynamic than previously thought with the studies of several active galactic nuclei in the process of "turning on" indicating changes in the rate of material accreting onto the central black hole. 


ZTF has also proven to be a treasure chest for stellar astronomy with the identification of many new examples of rare stellar types, along with violent stellar outbursts from flaring stars and cataclysmic variables. In particular, ZTF has discovered the smallest and most massive white dwarf ever seen, which is itself the result of the merger of a white dwarf binary. It is so massive that it may further collapse into a neutron star and this could be a significant new formation channel for neutron stars. ZTF has also caught a star in the act of swallowing a planet whole for the first time which our own Sun is predicted to do in 5 billion years. 


ZTF is a powerful instrument for studies of the Solar System, and specifically for comets and asteroids. Tens of thousands of new Main Belt asteroids have been discovered as well as almost 300 Near Earth Objects. ZTF has been particularly productive for asteroids within the orbit of Earth and has also captured many comets in outburst which is important in understanding their composition and evolution. 


With its wide field-of-view, ZTF is also an ideal multi-messenger follow-up instrument with which to search for electromagnetic counterparts to gravitational waves and neutrinos. ZTF has promptly searched for optical flares from the mergers of binary neutron stars and binary black holes, helping to provide limits on the expected rates and detectability of such mergers. It has also detected a TDE event that may be associated with a high-energy neutrino detection. 


Finally, ZTF has been vital to the education of the astronomical community about real-time transient astronomy and the development of community infrastructure to prepare for the alerts to come from the Rubin Observatory. A number of community alert brokers are now in regular operation, having partnered with ZTF and the 400 million public alerts it has produced over the course of the project.
